_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Nebraska Beef, Ltd. (Nebraska Beef), located in Omaha, Nebraska, provides refrigeration for meat processed from carcasses.  Nebraska Beef?s senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Nebraska Beef administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP).  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ammonia refrigeration system was installed at Nebraska Beef in 1995.  Nebraska Beef began operations at the facility in 1995.  The facility is located at 4501 South 36th Street, Omaha, Nebraska 68107.  The system was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.

The system uses 75,322 pounds of ammonia to provide refrigeration for meat processed from carcasses.  The majority of the system including vessels and compressors is located within facility walls.  The condensers are mounted on the roof and all of the evaporators are located in their respective freezer/cold storage areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Nebraska Beef ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.    For example, the Nebraska Beef operates in accordance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management regulation.

Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: ammonia sensors that sounds an alarm to the ammonia operator, re

lief valves on all pressure vessels, and continuous ventilation in the engine rooms to prevent ammonia explosions.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility has based its maintenance program on the industry standard: the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems? is used at the facility.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Nebraska Beef facility located in Omaha, Nebraska, has not had any reportable ammonia releases over the last five years (November 2000 through November 2005).

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Nebraska Beef has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

Nebraska Beef maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed on November 30, 2004, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Nebraska Beef facility located at 4501 South 36th Street, Nebraska 68107.  The Nebraska Beef safety committee has completed several items, includ

ing the recommendations, in a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.    Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.    Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
